You are playing the Bulls and Cows number guessing game. The rules are:
1. There is a secret 4-digit number you need to guess (using digits 0-9)
2. Each digit (0-9) can appear at most once in the number
3. After each guess, you'll receive:
   - Bulls: number of digits that are correct AND in the right position
   - Cows: number of digits that are correct BUT in the wrong position

You can explain your reasoning before making a guess.
Always end your response with a line starting with 'GUESS:' followed by your 4-digit number.
DO NOT use any other formatting (e.g., Markdown or bold) in the last line of your response.
Let's start the game. Make your first guess:

For the first guess, I’ll use a combination that spreads out lower digits, which can help in gathering information about which ones might be present. I'll guess 0123.

GUESS: 0123
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

From the first guess we know that exactly one digit among 0, 1, 2, or 3 appears in the secret number—but not in the same position as we tried before. I’ll pick one digit from that group (choosing 2) and place it in a new position (position 1 instead of position 3). Then I’ll test three completely new digits (4, 5, and 6) to see if any of them are part of the secret number. This will help determine whether the secret includes additional digits from outside the first group.

So my next guess is 2456.

GUESS: 2456
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

We know from the first guess (0123) that exactly one digit among 0, 1, 2, or 3 is in the secret number (but in a different position), and from the second guess (2456) that exactly two digits among 2, 4, 5, or 6 are present (again, each not in the position we used). Notice that the digit 2 appears in both groups. This leads us to two potential scenarios for the candidate from the first group:
 • Either the one digit from {0,1,2,3} is 2 (which would then be one of our two from {2,4,5,6} – meaning the secret would then contain 2 plus one more from {4,5,6}),
 • Or it is one of 0, 1, or 3 (so in this case the two digits from the second guess would come solely from {4,5,6}, and 2 would not be in the secret).

My plan now is to include digit 2 (to test if it is that common candidate), one choice from the remaining {0,1,3} – I’ll use 1, and also include a candidate from the set {4,5,6} – I’ll choose 4, then add one completely new digit (7) so we start testing outside of the previous guesses. 

We must be careful with placement: for digit 2, we cannot use positions 2 (from guess 0123) or 0 (from guess 2456), so I’ll put it in position 1; for digit 1, it shouldn’t be in position 1 (since it was there in guess 0123), so I’ll assign it to position 0; for digit 4, recall it was in position 1 in guess 2456, so I’ll move it to position 2; and 7 is new so it can go anywhere, so I’ll put it in position 3.

Thus the next guess is 1-2-4-7 (1247). The feedback will help us decide if digit 2 is indeed in the secret or if the digit from {0,1,3} is 1 (and consequently 2 is not present). 

GUESS: 1247
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our goal is now to test whether digit 2 (the common candidate from previous guesses) is actually in the secret. Recall:
• Guess1 (0123) told us exactly one digit from {0,1,2,3} is present. That candidate is either 2 or one of {0,1,3}.
• Guess2 (2456) told us exactly two digits from {2,4,5,6} are present. So if 2 is the candidate from Guess1, then one more digit among {4,5,6} is in the secret; if not, then the two digits come solely from {4,5,6}.
• Guess3 (1247) again yielded 0 bulls and 2 cows. In one scenario (let’s call it Scenario A) the secret contains 2 (and likely 4) while in the alternative (Scenario B) it contains 1 (from Guess1) and 4 from Guess2.

We can distinguish between these scenarios by forcing digit 2 into its only allowed position if it is present. (From earlier feedback, if 2 is in the secret it cannot be in the same positions it appeared in prior guesses: it was in position 2 in Guess1, position 0 in Guess2, and position 1 in Guess3. Thus in Scenario A digit 2 must be at position 3.)

I propose the next guess: 8 in position 0, 1 in position 1, 4 in position 2, and 2 in position 3 (i.e. 8-1-4-2). Let’s see how the feedback would differ:
• In Scenario A (secret contains 2 and 4, but not 1), comparing guess 8,1,4,2 to the secret:
 – The 2 in position 3 will be a bull (because if 2 is included it must be in position 3).
 – The 4, though present, is placed at position 2 while secret’s allowed positions for 4 are only index0 or index3 (from earlier guesses), so it becomes a cow.
 – The digits 8 and 1 should be absent.
 This would yield 1 bull and 1 cow.
• In Scenario B (secret contains 1 and 4, but not 2):
 – The 2 (at position 3) would be absent.
 – The 1, if present, must be in allowed positions (indices 2 or 3 based on earlier information), so with it placed at index1 in our guess it gives a cow.
 – The 4, again forced to be in index0 or index3 if present, placed at index2 gives a cow.
 – 8 is absent.
 This would yield 0 bulls and 2 cows.

Thus, the feedback on this guess will let us tell whether 2 is in the secret (Scenario A) or not (Scenario B).

GUESS: 8142
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our deductions have led us to narrow the secret’s digits down to four numbers. Here’s what we know from all previous feedback:

• From 0123 (0 bulls, 1 cow), exactly one digit from {0,1,2,3} is in the secret. Since digit 2 cannot be in the secret (because every guess placing 2 in a different position yielded 0 bulls), the candidate from this set must be either 0, 1, or 3.

• From 2456 (0 bulls, 2 cows) and knowing 2 is ruled out, exactly two digits from {4,5,6} are in the secret. Their common element with our later guesses turns out to be 4. (In fact, comparing with the next steps, 4 appears in all intersections, so it must be in the secret.) That leaves the other digit from {4,5,6} to be either 5 or 6.

• From 1247 (0 bulls, 2 cows) and 8142 (0 bulls, 2 cows), comparing intersections with {1,2,4,7} and {8,1,4,2} – eliminating 2 – forces the other certain intersection to be {1,4}. Since we already have 4, it follows that 1 must be in the secret. (The candidate in {0,1,3} is thus 1.)

So at this point the secret’s digit set is forced to be exactly {1,4,9,?} because there is only one digit left “outside” these intersections. Notice that the union of the four digits coming from the tested sets (namely {0,1,2,3}, {2,4,5,6}, {1,2,4,7} and {8,1,4,2}) covers 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8. Since all feedback counts are exact, the only remaining digit that can “fill the gap” is 9. In addition, from {4,5,6} we already have 4, so the other digit from that set must come from {5,6}. Thus the secret must be composed of 1, 4, 9 and either 5 or 6.

To determine which candidate from {5,6} is correct, we can design a guess that tests the presence of 6. Notice that if the secret includes 6 then its digit set is {1,4,6,9} (i.e. all guessed digits in our next attempt), and if not then the secret’s set is {1,4,5,9} (yielding only three shared digits with a guess that includes 6).

I propose using the guess 4916 arranged as follows:
 • Place 4 at position 0 (allowed since guess2 had 4 at position 1 and guess3/4 had 4 in position 2).
 • Place 9 at position 1 (9 is new, so no restrictions).
 • Place 1 at position 2 (1 was previously at positions 0 and 1 in earlier guesses, so pos2 is allowed).
 • Place 6 at position 3 (if 6 is in the secret it cannot be in position 3 based on guess2, so if we get overall four matches it tells us 6 is present).

Now, if the secret’s set is {1,4,6,9} the guess 4916 will match all four digits (yielding a total of 4 matches, with bulls depending on placement) whereas if the secret is {1,4,5,9} then the intersection with 4916 is only {1,4,9} (three digits). The resulting total count (bulls plus cows) will let us distinguish which candidate is in the secret.

GUESS: 4916
Your last guess resulted in: 2 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

We already know the secret’s four digits are 1, 4, 9, and 6 because guess 4916 yielded 2 bulls and 2 cows (meaning all digits are correct but only two are in the proper spot). To determine the correct order, we need to choose a different permutation that will help us distinguish among the (few) possible arrangements.

One approach is to rearrange 4, 9, 1, and 6 in a way that, combined with the 2 bulls 2 cows result from 4916, will eliminate some candidate orderings. For example, let’s consider the guess 1694. Here’s a brief look at what happens with candidate secret orders:

Assume the secret is one permutation of {1,4,9,6} that would have produced 2 bulls/2 cows when compared with 4916. (For instance, if in guess 4916 the bulls came from positions 1 and 3, one candidate would be 9,4,1,6; there are a few such possibilities.) When we play 1694:
 • If the secret were 1,9,6,4 for example, comparing with 1694 would give 2 bulls (positions 0 and 3) and 2 cows (the other two digits swapped).
 • Other candidates would yield feedback differing from 2 bulls/2 cows. Thus, the result of this guess will help us understand the correct ordering.

I’ll now submit 1694 as our next guess.

GUESS: 1694
Your last guess resulted in: 1 bulls (correct position) and 3 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

From our previous guesses we deduced that the secret’s digits are exactly 1, 4, 9, and 6. Evaluating our earlier two guesses:

• For 4916 we had 2 bulls and 2 cows, meaning that two digits were in the right spot while all four digits were present.
• For 1694 we got 1 bull and 3 cows, again confirming that all digits are correct but only one is placed correctly.

Let’s denote the secret as S0 S1 S2 S3. One candidate that satisfies these conditions is S0=6, S1=9, S2=1, S3=4. Checking:
 – For guess 4916:
  • Position 0: 4 vs. 6  → not a bull; 4 appears in S3 → cow.
  • Position 1: 9 vs. 9  → bull.
  • Position 2: 1 vs. 1  → bull.
  • Position 3: 6 vs. 4  → not a bull; 6 appears in S0 → cow.
  Result: 2 bulls, 2 cows.
 – For guess 1694:
  • Position 0: 1 vs. 6  → not a bull; 1 appears in S2 → cow.
  • Position 1: 6 vs. 9  → not a bull; 6 in S0 → cow.
  • Position 2: 9 vs. 1  → not a bull; 9 in S1 → cow.
  • Position 3: 4 vs. 4  → bull.
  Result: 1 bull, 3 cows.

Both match our feedback. With confidence in this candidate, I’ll use 6914 as my guess.

GUESS: 6914
Your last guess resulted in: 1 bulls (correct position) and 3 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our deductions now point to a secret composed of the digits 1, 4, 9, and 6. Let’s review our key comparisons:

• For the guess 4916, we got 2 bulls and 2 cows, which indicates that all four digits are correct but exactly two are in the proper positions.
• For the guess 1694, we got 1 bull and 3 cows.
• For the guess 6914, we also got 1 bull and 3 cows.

Assume the secret is s0 s1 s2 s3, with s0, s1, s2, s3 being a permutation of {1,4,9,6}. Testing the candidate secret 1-9-4-6:
 – Comparing with 4916:
  • Position 0: Guess 4 vs. S0=1 → no bull; 4 appears at S2 → cow.
  • Position 1: Guess 9 vs. S1=9 → bull.
  • Position 2: Guess 1 vs. S2=4 → no bull; 1 appears at S0 → cow.
  • Position 3: Guess 6 vs. S3=6 → bull.
  Result: 2 bulls, 2 cows.
 – Comparing with 1694:
  • Position 0: 1 vs. 1 → bull.
  • Position 1: 6 vs. 9 → not a bull; 6 is at S3 → cow.
  • Position 2: 9 vs. 4 → not a bull; 9 is at S1 → cow.
  • Position 3: 4 vs. 6 → not a bull; 4 is at S2 → cow.
  Result: 1 bull, 3 cows.
 – Comparing with 6914:
  • Position 0: 6 vs. 1 → not a bull; 6 is at S3 → cow.
  • Position 1: 9 vs. 9 → bull.
  • Position 2: 1 vs. 4 → not a bull; 1 is at S0 → cow.
  • Position 3: 4 vs. 6 → not a bull; 4 is at S2 → cow.
  Result: 1 bull, 3 cows.

All feedback aligns perfectly with the candidate secret 1946. To confirm, I will now guess 1946.

GUESS: 1946
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 4 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Based on all the clues so far, the secret’s digits are exactly 1, 4, 9, and 6. When we guessed 1946 we got 0 bulls and 4 cows, which tells us the secret is a derangement of 1, 9, 4, 6 (i.e. all digits are in the secret but none are in the positions they appeared in "1946"). There are several possible derangements, but testing them against our feedback from previous guesses narrows it down.

For example, comparing candidate 4619 to our previous results:
 • Against 4916 (guess “4 9 1 6”): 4619 gives bulls at positions 0 and 2 (4 and 1) and cows for 6 and 9 – yielding 2 bulls and 2 cows.
 • Against 1694 (guess “1 6 9 4”): 4619 gives a bull when the guessed digit “6” is out of place and the others appear in different positions – yielding 1 bull and 3 cows.
 • Against 6914: 4619 again yields 1 bull and 3 cows.
 • And against 1946 we already have 0 bulls and 4 cows.

Every feedback aligns with the candidate secret being 4619.

GUESS: 4619

From our first guess (0123), we know none of the digits were in the correct position but exactly one of them is present elsewhere in the secret. This means exactly one of 0, 1, 2, or 3 is in the secret number, but not in the position guessed (0 in first, 1 in second, 2 in third, 3 in fourth).

For our next guess, we want to test new digits while including exactly one candidate from 0, 1, 2, or 3, but in a different position than before. I’ll include the digit 2 (which was in the third position before, so I’ll try it elsewhere) and add three fresh digits to check against. Let’s try 2 in the first position followed by 4, 5, and 6 so that if 2 is indeed the correct candidate digit, it will be revealed in a new spot, and we’ll also gather information about 4, 5, and 6.

GUESS: 2456

From our second guess (2456) we learned that exactly two of the digits are correctly placed, and none of the other two appear anywhere in the secret. It’s very likely that one of these bulls is the repeated candidate from our first guess – the digit 2 – because it appeared in guess 0123 (yielding 1 cow) and then reappeared in guess 2456. If 2 truly belongs to the secret, then its bull in guess 2456 must come from being correctly placed in position 1 (since it wasn’t in its original position in guess 0123). That would set secret digit 1 as 2.

Now one of the other digits in 2456 (4, 5, or 6) is the other bull in the same positions as guessed (positions 2, 3, or 4, respectively), while the remaining two digits in 2456 are definitely not part of the secret at all.

To narrow which of 4, 5, or 6 is that extra bull, we can try to “probe” one of these positions. My plan is to keep the presumed bait digit 2 in the first position and test one of the candidate digits (say, 4) in its original position (position 2) while introducing two new digits (7 and 8) in the other positions. 

If the bull count in this new guess is 2 then that would strongly indicate that 2 in position 1 and 4 in position 2 are indeed correct—pinning down two digits in their right spots. (If instead the bull count drops to 1, then while 2 is still likely in place, 4 would be ruled out and the other candidate from guess 2456 would be the hidden bull, letting us focus our search.)

With that reasoning, my next guess is:

GUESS: 2478

1. There is a secret 4-digit number you need to guess (using digits 0-9)
2. Each digit (0-9) can appear at most once in the number
3. After each guess, you'll receive:
   - Bulls: number of digits that are correct AND in the right position
   - Cows: number of digits that are correct BUT in the wrong position

You can explain your reasoning before making a guess.
Always end your response with a line starting with 'GUESS:' followed by your 4-digit number.

Let's start the game. Make your first guess:

I'll start with a guess that uses several different digits to help narrow down which ones are in the secret number. Using 0, 1, 2, and 3 allows us to quickly learn whether any of these digits belong to the secret number and also check their positions if they turn out to be correct. Let's see what the response tells us, and then we can adjust our next guess accordingly.
GUESS: 0123
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

From our first guess (0123) we learned that exactly one digit among 0, 1, 2, and 3 is present in the secret number (and it’s in a different position than in 0123). For our next guess, I want to test some new digits while still including one digit from that set – in this case I’ll include 0 again but in a new position to check if it really is the candidate.

I’ll use the digits 4, 5, and 6 as new candidates. In the guess 4056, the digit 0 moves from the first position (in 0123) to the second position. If the secret number contains 0 (but not in that position), we should get a cow; if not then it implies the candidate digit from our first guess is among 1, 2, or 3. The appearance (or absence) of any of these new digits in the bulls/cows count will help us further narrow down the options.

GUESS: 4056
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our two earlier guesses tell us:
• In 0123 we got 0 bulls and 1 cow – so exactly one digit from {0, 1, 2, 3} is in the secret number (but in another position).
• In 4056 we got 0 bulls and 1 cow – so exactly one digit from {4, 0, 5, 6} is in the secret number.

Notice that 0 appears in both groups. One possibility is that 0 is the common candidate (appearing only once in the secret number). Alternatively, it might be that the candidate from 0123 is one of {1, 2, 3} while the candidate from 4056 is one of {4, 5, 6}.

To help distinguish these cases and also to test new, untried digits (we haven’t seen 7, 8, or 9 yet), I propose a guess that uses three completely new digits plus the digit 0 from our previous guesses. This guess is 7890. Here’s the plan:
• If 0 is indeed the secret digit from our earlier tests, then using 0 (now in a new position) will produce either a bull (if it happens to fall in its correct spot) or a cow.
• If 0 is not in the secret number, then our guess will register 0 bulls and 0 cows (since 7, 8, 9 are new and none of the candidates from earlier appear), which will tell us that our secret digits likely come from {1, 2, 3} and {4, 5, 6}.

This information will significantly narrow down our choices for the secret number.

GUESS: 7890
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our earlier deductions indicate the secret number must consist of the following:
• Exactly one digit from {1,2,3} must be in the secret, and since 1 from our guess 1478 did not match, that candidate must be 2 or 3.
• Exactly one digit from {4,5,6} must be in the secret, and since 4 from 1478 wasn’t in the secret, the candidate is either 5 or 6.
• Exactly two digits from {7,8,9} are in the secret, and the responses point toward those being 7 and 8 (since our guess 7890 produced 2 cows even though 0 was ruled out, and 1478 only produced 2 cows, suggesting that both candidates from group 3 are the ones we used there).

So, we’re now almost sure the secret digits are {7,8} from group 3; plus one of {2,3} from group 1; plus one of {5,6} from group 2.

To probe the exact digits and begin checking positions, I’ll try a new guess that uses one candidate from each of the uncertain groups in an order different from before. For instance, if I guess 7285 then:
• I use 7 in position 1 and 8 in position 3 for group 3.
• I use 2 (from group 1) in position 2 and 5 (from group 2) in position 4.
If this guess returns 4 bulls, we have solved it. If not, the bulls (and cows) count will help decide whether to swap 2 for 3 or 5 for 6 and/or adjust the positions of 7 and 8.

GUESS: 7285
Your last guess resulted in: 1 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

We’ve deduced that the secret number’s digits are {3, 6, 7, 8}. Here’s a brief recap of our logic:

• In 0123 we got 0 bulls, 1 cow, meaning exactly one digit among {0,1,2,3} is in the secret. Since our eventual candidate set does not include 0, that one must be 3 (not 1 or 2, as they must be ruled out later).

• In 4056 we received 0 bulls, 1 cow, so exactly one digit from {4,0,5,6} is in the secret. With 0 ruled out and 5 later eliminated by other responses, the candidate here is 6.

• In 7890, 0 bulls and 2 cows told us that exactly two digits from {7,8,9,0} appear in the secret. With 0 out and 9 not showing up in the other clues, the two are 7 and 8.

• In 1478 we got 0 bulls, 2 cows. The only common digits from that guess with our candidate set are 7 and 8; they must both be present but in different positions than in 1478 (which had 7 in third position and 8 in fourth).

• Finally, in 7285 our guess produced 1 bull and 1 cow. Given that 7, 2, 8, 5 are in the guess and our candidate digits include 7 and 8 (with 2 and 5 eliminated from previous elimination, since otherwise the intersection count would be higher), one of 7 or 8 must be exactly positioned (bull) and the other present elsewhere (cow). Analyzing the other position prohibitions (for instance, from 7890 and 1478) forces 8 to be in third position (since in 7285 the only possible bull is if the third digit, 8, is in its correct place) and 7 in a different spot (not pos1 because in 7890, 7 in pos1 would have given a bull).

One more observation came from “0123” and “4056”: neither 3 nor 6 can occupy their fourth positions (since that would have given bulls in those guesses when 3 is in pos4 of 0123 or 6 is in pos4 of 4056). With the forced placement in 7285, and the conditions from 1478 (7 cannot be in pos3 and 8 cannot be in pos4), the only consistent arrangement is to have 8 in position 3 and 7 in position 4. That leaves positions 1 and 2 for 3 and 6; either order yields the same hit counts so far. I’ll choose one consistent arrangement: 3 in pos1 and 6 in pos2.

Thus our candidate secret number is 3,6,8,7. I propose the next guess as:

GUESS: 3687
Your last guess resulted in: 1 bulls (correct position) and 0 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Based on all our feedback so far, I’ve gone back over the constraints:

• 0123 gave 0 bulls, 1 cow, meaning exactly one of {0,1,2,3} is in the secret.
• 4056 gave 0 bulls, 1 cow, so exactly one digit from {4,0,5,6} is in the secret.
• 7890 gave 0 bulls, 2 cows, which tells us exactly two of {7,8,9,0} make it into the secret.
• 1478 gave 0 bulls, 2 cows, so exactly two of {1,4,7,8} are in the secret.
• 7285 gave 1 bull, 1 cow, meaning two of its digits are in the secret with one perfectly placed.
• 3687 in our most recent guess returned 1 bull and 0 cows; note that 3687 ∩ our candidate set from previous guesses was assumed to be {3,6,7,8} but now only one digit appears in the secret and exactly in its position.

Reconciling these counts led me to reassign the candidate digits. The consistent solution turns out to be that the secret’s digits (in some order) are from:
 • Exactly one from {1,2,3} – we find that 2 works.
 • Exactly one from {4,0,5,6} – here 4 appears.
 • And exactly two from {7,8,9,0} – and from the other constraints these turn out to be 7 and 9.
In addition, the last guess (3687) tells us that the only matching digit from {3,6,8,7} is 7, and it must be exactly in the right spot (position 4, as 7 is the only candidate that can match in that guess).

Working through positions using the bull restrictions from earlier guesses—for example, 4056 ruled out 4 in position1 and 1478 ruled out 4 in pos2—leads to placing 4 in position 3. With 7 fixed in position 4 (from guess 3687) and having one candidate from {1,2,3} (which must be 2 to satisfy the count in guess 0123) and one candidate from {4,0,5,6} already set to 4, our two remaining digits among the two from {7,8,9} must be 7 and 9. With 7 already in pos4, the other one is 9. Finally, placing 2 and 9 in positions1 and 2 while obeying clues (for instance, guess7285 requires that 2 appears as a bull if in position2 while 7 is counted as a mispositioned cow) yields the only arrangement:

Position1: 9
Position2: 2
Position3: 4
Position4: 7

This secret number 9247 satisfies:
 – 0123 gives only the digit 2 (in secret pos2 ≠ guess pos3) → 1 cow.
 – 4056 gives only 4 (in secret pos3 ≠ guess pos1) → 1 cow.
 – 7890 gives 9 and 7 as cows.
 – 1478 gives 4 and 7 as cows.
 – 7285 gives 2 as a bull (secret pos2 = guess pos2) and 7 as a cow.
 – 3687 gives 7 exactly in the right place (secret pos4 = guess pos4) and no other overlap.

Thus the next guess is:

GUESS: 9247
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our accumulated clues have narrowed the secret number’s digits to four unique ones. Here’s a summary under our current working assumptions with 8 as the candidate from guess 6 (in 3687, where only one digit in that guess is correct and in position):

• Guess 6 (3687, 1 bull, 0 cows) tells us that among {3,6,8,7} exactly one digit is in the secret and it’s exactly placed. We choose 8 as that digit and place it in position 3.
• Guess 1 (0123, 0 bulls, 1 cow) means exactly one digit among {0,1,2,3} is in the secret. With 3 ruled out from guess 6 and no other clues favoring 0, a likely candidate is 1 (or 2), but we will see how the other clues line up.
• Guess 2 (4056, 0 bulls, 1 cow) indicates that among {4,0,5,6} exactly one digit is present. With 6 ruled out by our guess 6 assumption and 0 being a possible candidate but less favored by other groups, we lean toward 5 or 4.
• Guess 3 (7890, 0 bulls, 2 cows) shows that two digits among {7,8,9,0} are present. We already have 8; therefore one more from {9,0} must be in the secret.
• Guess 4 (1478, 0 bulls, 2 cows) tells us that two digits among {1,4,7,8} are present. With 8 present from guess 6 and 7 not showing up in our other deductions, it must be that one of {1,4} is present in addition to 8.
• Guess 5 (7285, 1 bull, 1 cow) has digits {7,2,8,5}. We already know that our secret has 8 in position 3 (because that guess shows 8 in pos3 giving a bull if that’s correct), so the extra matching digit here must be 5 or 2. But if we pick 2 from guess 5, then we must reconcile it with guess 1 (which would then have two possible candidates from {1,2,?}), so 5 is a stronger candidate.
• Finally, Guess 7 (9247, 0 bulls, 1 cow) involves digits {9,2,4,7}. Its single match forces the only candidate from this set to be 9 (if we select 2 or 4 we’d conflict with other group counts).

Thus a consistent candidate set is {1,5,8,9}.

  – And the confirmed digits 4, 6, and (by elimination) 9.

Now, before narrowing further, we’d like to test which candidate from {0,2,3} is present. Combining constraints for digit 4:

With secret digits {2,4,7,8} and 4 fixed in pos2, a candidate ordering that respects the other restrictions is as follows:

 • Two additional digits from {0,9} – and the clues force these to be 0 and 9.
In other words, the secret’s digit‐set is either {0,3,5,9} or {0,4,5,9}.

Careful cross‐checking forces the candidate from {1,2,3,4} to be either 3 or 4. Moreover, the candidate from {5,6,7,8} must be 5; and to match the counts, both 0 and 9 must be present in the set for one of our scenarios. Consistency with all previous feedback leaves us with exactly two possibilities:
 Secret = {0,3,5,9} or Secret = {0,4,5,9}.

To decide between these two options we need a guess that “tests” the ambiguity. In our next guess we want to include both 3 and 4 even though we know only one of them is in S. In addition we include two digits that we are sure about (0 and 5) and omit 9 (since it is common to both possibilities). Then the total number of matching digits (regardless of bulls versus cows) will differ:

This guess, 3075, contains 3 and 0 and 5 from our “sure” set and substitutes 7 for 4/9. Notice:

 • If instead the secret is {0,4,5,9}, then only 0 and 5 are present among the guessed digits (two digits match).
Thus, the total count of matching digits reported (bulls+cows) will differ between the two cases and help us decide whether the group‑1 candidate is 3 or 4.

• Or the secret’s digit from {0,1,2,3} is 0, 1, or 3 – in which case secret has none of the digit 2, and must include two digits from {4,5,6}.

To help distinguish these, I’ll construct a guess that uses exactly one candidate digit from the first group (choosing 2) and two from the second group (say 4 and 5) and include one new digit to expand our probe. I must also avoid positions that we already know are impossible for these digits (from our previous feedback). For example, since 2 was in position 3 in 0123 and in position 2 in 4256, we can try placing 2 in position 1; 4 was in position 1 in 4256 so we can place it in a different slot (I’ll put it in position 3); and 5 was in position 3 in 4256 so I’ll put it in position 4. This guess, 2745, will help clarify whether 2 is indeed the candidate from {0,1,2,3} and which other digit from {4,5,6} might be present. 

GUESS: 2745
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

We can combine our earlier clues as follows. From the first guess (0123) we know exactly one digit among {0, 1, 2, 3} is in the secret number. In our second guess (4256) we got two cows from {4, 2, 5, 6} and from our third guess (2745) we again got two cows for digits {2, 7, 4, 5}. (Remember that every secret digit appears only once.) But note that digit 2 appears in both groups, so we have two possible scenarios:

• Option 1: The secret’s unique digit from {0,1,2,3} is 2. Then among the digits in {4,2,5,6} one “hit” is 2 and the other must be either 4, 5, or 6. (And the feedback from guess 2745, which uses two of {2,4,5}, is explained by whether the extra digit is 4 or 5.)

• Option 2: The secret’s digit from {0,1,2,3} is not 2 (so it is 0, 1, or 3), and then the two “hits” from {4,2,5,6} must both come from {4,5,6} (with 2 being absent). But then look at guess 2745 (which gives two cows) whose common digits from {2,7,4,5} must come from the two digits 4 and 5 (if 2 is not present), limiting the possibilities from that group.

There is an additional positional restriction. For example, if 2 is in the secret (Option 1) then it cannot be in any position where it was guessed in previous rounds. In guess 0123 digit 2 was in position 3, in guess 4256 2 was in position 2, and in guess 2745 2 was in position 1. So in Option 1 the digit 2 would have to be in position 4. To help us distinguish (and especially to test whether 2 is in the secret – and if it is, it must appear in the fourth position), I propose a guess that puts 2 in position 4 and rearranges a couple of digits from our earlier clues. All feedbacks meet the reported numbers. 

Thus, my next guess based on these deductions is 5914.

Let's review what we know so far with our five guesses:

Setting up indicator equations (with x_d = 1 if digit d is in the secret, else 0) produces a system whose solution shows that the secret must contain exactly four digits. A careful analysis leads to the following restrictions on membership:

 • Moreover, equation (1) forces that exactly one of {0, 1, 2, 3} is used, and with 1 and 2 ruled out by other equations, the “extra” digit is either 0 or 3.

Additional restrictions based on the positions in our guesses (remember no bull ever occurred, so whenever a digit appeared it was not in its secret position) further constrain the secret’s arrangement. To differentiate these two possibilities, we can design a guess that uses the four digits {3, 5, 6, 7}. Let's start the game. Make your first guess:

For my first guess I'll use 1234. This guess uses four unique digits in consecutive order so that we can quickly identify which digits might be in the secret number and eliminate a large number of possibilities based on the response.

GUESS: 1234
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our first guess (1234) returned 0 bulls and 2 cows. That tells us exactly two of the four digits 1, 2, 3, and 4 are in the secret number – but in different positions than in 1234 – and the other two digits are not in the secret number at all.

For our next guess, I want to both retest some of those digits (but placing them in positions different from their positions in 1234) and introduce two entirely new digits to probe further. In 1234, the digits were in these positions:
 Position 1: 1
 Position 2: 2
 Position 3: 3
 Position 4: 4
Since we know that if a digit from 1234 is in the secret number, it must not be in that same position, we can try using two candidates from {1,2,3,4} but place them in different positions. I’ll choose 1 and 2 as the candidates from 1234, but I won’t put 1 in position 1 or 2 in position 2. The remaining two positions I fill with new digits (which come from the set of digits not yet eliminated – that is, not from 1,2,3,4). Here, I will try 5 and 6.

One possible arrangement is:
 Position 1: 5 (a new digit)
 Position 2: 1 (digit 1, not in its original position from 1234)
 Position 3: 2 (digit 2, moved from its original position)
 Position 4: 6 (a new digit)

This guess (5126) will tell us whether 1 and 2 are indeed the two digits from our previous guess; if we get a bull for one of them, we learn about its correct position. Also, if one or both of the new digits (5 and 6) appear in the secret number, we will detect that as well.

GUESS: 5126
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 2 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Our previous two guesses give us the following information:

• Guess 1234 resulted in 0 bulls and 2 cows. This tells us exactly two of {1, 2, 3, 4} are in the secret number—but not in the positions shown.
• Guess 5126 resulted in 0 bulls and 2 cows. This tells us exactly two of {5, 1, 2, 6} are in the secret number—but again in different positions.

Notice that digits 1 and 2 are common to both guesses. There are a few scenarios that could explain these results:

1. Both 1 and 2 are in the secret number (and thus account for both cows in each guess) and none of {3, 4, 5, 6} are.
2. Only one of 1 or 2 is in the secret number, with the other cow coming from {3, 4} in the first guess and from {5, 6} in the second guess.
3. Neither 1 nor 2 is in the secret number—in which case the two cows in the first guess come from {3, 4} and the two cows in the second guess come from {5, 6} (meaning the secret number would be exactly {3, 4, 5, 6} in some order).

To differentiate between these possibilities, it is useful to test digits that we haven’t used before. In our earlier guesses we’ve covered {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, leaving {0, 7, 8, 9} untouched. If we make a guess consisting entirely of these four new digits, the number of cows we get will indicate how many of these completely new digits are actually in the secret number. For example:

• If the secret number is {3, 4, 5, 6} (scenario 3) then none of 0, 7, 8, or 9 are used and we should get 0 bulls and 0 cows.
• If the secret number includes some new digits (scenario 1 or 2 where additional digits come from these not-yet-tested ones) then we would expect to see one or two cows.

Thus, I will try the guess 0-7-8-9 to help us narrow down which scenario we’re in.

GUESS: 0789
Your last guess resulted in: 1 bulls (correct position) and 0 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

From the two initial guesses we can deduce the following. In guess 1234 we got 0 bulls and 2 cows, meaning exactly two of its digits (from the set {1,2,3,4}) are in the secret, but in different positions. Then in guess 5126 (digits {5,1,2,6}) we also got 0 bulls and 2 cows. Notice that the digits 1 and 2 appear in both guesses. Let’s define three groups based on these observations:

• Group A: {1,2} – common to both guesses,
• Group B: {3,4} – the other two digits from guess 1234,
• Group C: {5,6} – the other two digits from guess 5126.

For guess 1234, if we call “a” the count of Group A digits present and “b” for Group B, we have a + b = 2. For guess 5126, with “a” from Group A and “c” for Group C, we have a + c = 2. The only possibility (remember a, b, c can be 0, 1, or 2) is a = 1, b = 1, and c = 1. That is, exactly one digit from each group appears in the secret.

Now turn to guess 0789, which gave 1 bull and 0 cows. None of its digits besides that one bull is in the secret number. And since none of 1,2,3,4,5,6 can be from 0789, the secret’s fourth digit must come from {0,7,8,9}. Also, because the bull occurred in the same position as in the guess, the one candidate from {0,7,8,9} is in a specific position—for example, if it were 7 in position 2 (since guess 0789 has 7 in second position), then the secret’s second digit is 7. We now know that the secret’s four digits consist of one digit from each of these groups:
 • one from Group A: {1,2},
 • one from Group B: {3,4},
 • one from Group C: {5,6},
 • one from Group D: {0,7,8,9} (with its bull in the same position as in guess 0789).

To gather further clues about which candidate from each group is the secret and about their positions, I’ll propose a guess that takes one candidate from each group and reorders them. In the guess below I choose:
 – from Group A, I test 2,
 – from Group D, I choose 7 (recalling that 7 was in position 2 in guess 0789),
 – from Group B, I choose 3,
 – from Group C, I choose 5.
I then arrange these as follows:
 Position 1: 2  Position 2: 7  Position 3: 3  Position 4: 5

This guess (2735) uses one candidate from each group and, by comparing its bulls and cows with previous guesses, we will narrow down which digits are really in the secret number and what their positions are.

GUESS: 2735
Your last guess resulted in: 1 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

Based on our earlier deductions, the responses tell us that exactly one digit from the pair {1,2} (Group A), one digit from {3,4} (Group B) and one from {5,6} (Group C) are present; the remaining digit must come from {0,7,8,9} (Group D) and we know from guess 0789 that one of these appears in the same cell as in that guess. A promising scenario was as follows:

• Assume the common digit is 2 from group A.
• Assume the candidate from group B is 4 (so that from 1234 the digits 2 and 4 appear, giving 2 cows).
• Assume the candidate from group C is 6 (so that from 5126 the digits 2 and 6 appear as cows).
• And let the Group D candidate be 7 (which appears in guess 0789 and—if placed correctly—yields 1 bull there).

A secret number built from these would be {2,4,6,7}. We must place them so that the previous guess results are honored. For example, if we arrange the secret as follows:

 Position 1: 4  Position 2: 7  Position 3: 6  Position 4: 2

Then we get:
 • Guess 1234 (digits 1,2,3,4): No digit is in its original position. However, both 2 and 4 are in the secret (though in different spots), giving exactly 2 cows.

You are playing the Bulls and Cows number guessing game. The rules are:
1. There is a secret 4-digit number you need to guess (using digits 0-9)
2. Each digit (0-9) can appear at most once in the number
3. After each guess, you'll receive:
   - Bulls: number of digits that are correct AND in the right position
   - Cows: number of digits that are correct BUT in the wrong position

Let's start the game. Make your first guess:

I'll start by covering a range of digits. My initial guess is "0123" to help identify which digits are present in the secret number and to gather positional clues from the bulls and cows feedback.

GUESS: 0123
Your last guess resulted in: 0 bulls (correct position) and 3 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

From our first guess, we know that three of the digits {0, 1, 2, 3} are in the secret number – exactly one of these is a “decoy.” However, we don’t yet know which one is not in the secret. Also, we know that none of these digits is in the same position that we used in “0123” (so secret: 0 is not in pos1, 1 not in pos2, 2 not in pos3, and 3 not in pos4).

That is, if the secret’s candidate set is actually {0, 2, 3} (meaning 1 is the extra one), then we should match three digits (though in different positions). Otherwise, if one or more of 2, 0, or 3 is not in the secret (and 1 is among the true ones), we’ll see fewer matches. In addition, the placement of these digits is arranged so none falls into the position they had in “0123.”

This guess “2034” should give us more insight into which candidate from the original four is missing and whether the new digit 4 might be in the secret.

Your last guess resulted in: 2 bulls (correct position) and 1 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

• From our first guess "0123" we know that three of the digits 0, 1, 2, 3 are in the secret but in different positions than in "0123." In other words, exactly one of those four does not appear in the secret.
• From our second guess "2034" we learned that only three of its digits match the secret (since we got 2 bulls and 1 cow) so one digit in that guess is not in the secret.
Notice that the intersection of {0, 1, 2, 3} (candidates from guess 1) and {2, 0, 3, 4} (from guess 2) is {0, 2, 3}. That strongly suggests the secret contains 0, 2, and 3 and is missing 1 (from guess 1) as well as 4 (from guess 2).

Thus the secret’s digit set appears to be {0, 2, 3} plus one additional digit X that is not among 0,1,2,3,4. (So X is one of 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9.)

We also have some positional restrictions:
• From guess "0123": Since 0 was guessed in position 1 (and it turned up as a cow), 0 can’t be in position 1; similarly, 2 can’t be in position 3 and 3 can’t be in position 4.
• From the feedback on guess "2034": Only three of its digits appear in the secret. Since they most likely are 2, 0, and 3, we can try to “place” them by testing different orders. One arrangement that meets both feedback sets is to have the secret arranged as follows:
  Position 1: 2  (Position 1 in guess "2034" is 2 → would then be a bull)
  Position 2: unknown X (our extra digit from {5–9})
  Position 3: 3  (Position 3 in guess "2034" is 3 → a bull)
  Position 4: 0  (Position 4 in guess "2034" is 0? No—as guessed “2034” has 4 in pos4, 0 is elsewhere, so 0 shows as a cow)
Checking with guess "0123":
  Secret’s 2 in pos1 (guess “0123” pos3 =2 → cow)
  0 in pos4 (guess “0123” pos1 =0 → cow)
  3 in pos3 (guess “0123” pos4 =3 → cow)
No digit falls in the same (correct) position as in "0123," which is consistent with 0 bulls.
And with guess "2034":
  Pos1: secret 2 matches guess’s 2 → bull;
  Pos3: secret 3 matches guess’s 3 → bull;
  0, although present, is not in the same position (0 appears in guess “2034” at pos2, not pos4) → cow.
This exactly gives 2 bulls and 1 cow.

Given that, our best working hypothesis is that the secret is a permutation of {2, X, 3, 0} with X ∈ {5,6,7,8,9} and with the placement we noted (2 in position 1, X in position 2, 3 in position 3, 0 in position 4).

 • For Guess 3 “2830”:

   pos1: 2 (guess) vs X (secret) – no bull, but 2 is in secret pos4 → cow;
   pos2: 8 vs 0 – no match;
   pos3: 3 vs 3 → bull;
   pos4: 0 vs 2 – no bull, but 0 is secret pos2 → cow.
  That gives 1 bull and 2 cows, exactly as reported.

So the picture now is that the secret uses digits {0,2,3} placed in positions 2, 3, and 4 exactly as (0,3,2) and the unknown digit X (which must be one of {5,6,7,8,9} but note later we’ll see that X cannot be 8) sits in position 1.

One way to test whether X might be 9 is to “fill in” position 1 with 9 while leaving our deduced positions intact. In other words, we try the guess:

  Guess = 9 0 3 2

Let’s see what that would yield if the secret were (X,0,3,2):
 • If X = 9 (so the secret is 9,0,3,2), then comparing with “9032” we’d get:

 • If instead X is not 9 (say X ∈ {5,6,7}) then in “9032” we compare:

  – pos2: 0 vs 0 → bull;
  – pos3: 3 vs 3 → bull;
  – pos4: 2 vs 2 → bull.
  That would yield 3 bulls and 0 cows.

Thus, by guessing 9032 we can immediately tell if X is 9 (winning if we get 4 bulls) or not (if we get 3 bulls). In the latter case we’d know the arrangement “(X,0,3,2)” is correct and that X is one of {5,6,7}.

I will use 9032 as my next guess.

GUESS: 9032
Your last guess resulted in: 3 bulls (correct position) and 0 cows (wrong position). Make your next guess:

With our current information, the secret appears to have the structure:

  Position 2: 0

Recall:
 • "0123" resulted in 0 bulls and 3 cows, meaning that digits 0, 2, and 3 are in the secret but not in their original positions.
 • "2034" (digits: 2, 0, 3, 4) produced 2 bulls and 1 cow, consistent with 0, 2, and 3 being present and in a specific order.

 • Finally, "9032" yielded 3 bulls – positions 2 (0), 3 (3), and 4 (2) – confirming that these positions are fixed and that the remaining digit in position 1 is not 9.
